snippet.title: Navalny's conviction in Russia a chilling message
snippet.description: A Moscow judge on Tuesday left open the possibility of jailing President Vladimir Putin's main critic for years, a sign of Putin's increasingly hard-line rule against opponents.

snippet.title: Analysis: Putin likely to ignore West on Ukraine
snippet.description: Since he took over Crimea, President Vladimir Putin has seen his popularity soar and his opposition fall silent. So when the U.S. vice president told Russia to defuse tensions in Ukraine, Putin had few reasons to listen.

snippet.title: The logic of Russian Internet censorship
snippet.description: Why Russia blocks some opposition Web sites but not others.

snippet.title: Ukraine is Putin's, not Russia's, war
snippet.description: Don't confuse the actions of Russia's president with its people.

snippet.title: McFaul leaves Moscow â€” and two dramatic years in relations between U.S. and Russia
snippet.description: He arrived to rising anti-Americanism, dealt with U.S. AID expulsion, Magnitsky law, adoption ban.

snippet.title: World Digest: Feb. 25, 2014
snippet.description: Militants set fire to school in Nigeria, killing 58; Mexico plans to ensure accused drug lord is tried there first.

snippet.title: Pussy Riot performers visit Olympic city, where Sochi police quickly pick them up
snippet.description: The women were far from Olympics when picked up for questioning before being released.

snippet.title: U.S. ambassador in Moscow uses social media to bypass official line
snippet.description: Ambassador McFaul finds Twitter helps get American message out in age of digital diplomacy.

snippet.title: World Digest: Oct. 29, 2013
snippet.description: Judges in Muslim Brotherhood trial in Egypt step down; Russia brings new charges against Alexei Navalny.

snippet.title: Mr. Putin's czarist courts
snippet.description: The Kremlin finds a way to neutralize the Russian president's foremost opponent--if it works.
